content: Is it possible to have a non-symmetric monoidal structure on Set\mathsf{Set}Set? I asked someone and they mentioned that it seemed like it would have to do with formal power series, and that the answer was probably 'no'. But I thought I'd ask here in case someone knew of a more definitive answer.

I found some stuff about how monoidal structures could be generated by A⊗B=∑i,jSi,j×Ai×BjA \otimes B = \displaystyle \sum_{i,j} S_{i,j} × A^i × B^jA⊗B=i,j∑​Si,j​×Ai×Bj, but it seemed like the people talking about it didn't know definitively whether all monoidal structures were generated that way.

Interesting question! What are the conditions on the Si,jS_{i,j}Si,j​ to get a monoidal structure? It does not look like any choice of these would give you associativity at least. Do you have a link to share about these monoidal structures?

Dan Doel said:

I found some stuff about how monoidal structures could be generated by A⊗B=∑i,jSi,j×Ai×BjA \otimes B = \displaystyle \sum_{i,j} S_{i,j} × A^i × B^jA⊗B=i,j∑​Si,j​×Ai×Bj

This looks like the evaluation of a bivariate polynomial on (A,B)(A, B)(A,B)

@Antonin Delpeuch I'm not exactly sure. The discussion is here. I guess they're at least supposed to be 'natural numbers'. But I'm not sure if something like Si,j=Sj,iS_{i,j} = S_{j,i}Si,j​=Sj,i​ needs to hold. Possibly they aren't assuming that, but if it doesn't, the tensor won't actually be associative.
Wow that's a really nice discussion (which uses all sorts of notions I don't know at all), thanks! The proposed connection with analytic functions is exciting but also a bit daunting…

I haven't checked this in detail, so I may have made a simple oversight, but the following looks like a (nonsymmetric) semicartesian monoidal structure on Set. Let A⊗B=AA \otimes B = AA⊗B=A if ∣A∣≠1|A| \neq 1∣A∣=1 and BBB otherwise, and let f⊗gf \otimes gf⊗g be fff if neither its domain nor codomain has cardinality 1, and ggg otherwise. The operation picks the "leftmost non-singleton set", and is associative and unital, I think naturally.
Isn't that not functorial?
It may not be. I just realised I forgot to check.
I think stuff like that likely wouldn't be, even if it can be defined.
I'm actually asking due to this, and someone there suggested a similar thing with 000 instead of 111, which certainly fails to be functorial.
I would have thought if it doesn't work with 000 as the unit, it won't work with 111 as the unit either.

I wonder if there's an argument to be made that, being the free cocompletion of a point, the only monoidal operations must be expressible in terms of colimits, which must therefore be symmetric by the distributivity of colimits over colimits.

Well, for 000, I think the problem is that 0⊗B=B0 \otimes B = B0⊗B=B, but there is a unique map 0→A0 → A0→A, which should give you a choice of B→AB → AB→A for every AAA. However, composing with any A→CA → CA→C gives the unique map 0→C0 → C0→C, and must give the choice for CCC. However, first getting the choice for AAA and then composing with an A→CA → CA→C will not give the same result in general.
So I don't think that argument will work with 111, but my suspicion is that something else is wrong with it.

I don't actually think what I wrote is well-defined :sweat_smile: If we have 1→fA1 \xrightarrow{f} A1f​A and B→gCB \xrightarrow{g} CBg​C then we want a map 1⊗B→A⊗C1 \otimes B \to A \otimes C1⊗B→A⊗C = B→AB \to AB→A, but what I wrote gives a map from B→CB \to CB→C.
Oh yeah, that'd be a problem. :)

Dan Doel said:

I found some stuff about how monoidal structures could be generated by A⊗B=∑i,jSi,j×Ai×BjA \otimes B = \displaystyle \sum_{i,j} S_{i,j} × A^i × B^jA⊗B=i,j∑​Si,j​×Ai×Bj, but it seemed like the people talking about it didn't know definitively whether all monoidal structures were generated that way.

Where do the indices i,ji,ji,j run over? Depending on the answer, this might be interpreted as some sort of Day convolution. It really reminds me the convolution induced on [J,Set][{\cal J}, {\sf Set}][J,Set] by a promonoidal structure P:Jop×Jop×J→Set\mathfrak{P} : {\cal J}^\text{op}\times {\cal J}^\text{op} \times {\cal J} \to \sf SetP:Jop×Jop×J→Set: for all x∈Jx \in \cal Jx∈J,

A∗PB(x)=∫ijAi×Bj×Pijx \displaystyle A *_{\mathfrak P} B(x) = \int^{ij} A^i \times B^j \times P^x_{ij} A∗P​B(x)=∫ijAi×Bj×Pijx​

So what goes wrong if we take A⊗B≅AA \otimes B \cong AA⊗B≅A whenever AAA is non-empty and A⊗B≅BA \otimes B \cong BA⊗B≅B when AAA is empty? At first glance it seems functorial, associative and unitial with unit ∅\emptyset∅
At first glance it doesn't seem functorial to me... what are the maps supposed to be?
Given f:A→A′f:A \to A'f:A→A′ and g:B→B′g: B \to B'g:B→B′, f⊗gf \otimes gf⊗g is fff if AAA is inhabited and ggg if AAA is empty.
Ah, damn, if A′A'A′ is inhabited but not AAA, we need a morphism B→A′B \to A'B→A′, hmm

I suspect this could be settled by some case-analysis. Here is some lazy speculation... Consider 1⊗11 \otimes 11⊗1, for example: if it's empty, then since any pair of objects has a morphism !⊗!:A⊗B→1⊗1! \otimes !: A \otimes B \to 1 \otimes 1!⊗!:A⊗B→1⊗1, the monoidal product would have to be empty everywhere, which is not allowed. If 1⊗1≅11 \otimes 1 \cong 11⊗1≅1, (if I'm calculating this correctly), we get a comparison transformation from the cartesian product that sends (a,b)∈A×B(a,b) \in A \times B(a,b)∈A×B to a⊗b:1⊗1→A⊗Ba \otimes b: 1 \otimes 1 \to A \otimes Ba⊗b:1⊗1→A⊗B. This doesn't immediately preclude asymmetry, but perhaps there is some argument that can extend this line of reasoning.

If 1⊗1≅1+11 \otimes 1 \cong 1 + 11⊗1≅1+1, we should get a comparison morphism to the cocartesian monoidal structure, although actually constructing this requires some powerset shenanigans. If all of this serves to prevent any of these cases from being asymmetric, then we arrive at the final case which is that 1⊗11 \otimes 11⊗1 is "big" (has more than two elements). On the one hand, there might be room for asymmetry here, but I suspect that the unit will again cause problems, and possibly enough to prevent this case too.
@fosco I think it's supposed to be finite naturals, because it's like a formal power series.

@[Mod] Morgan Rogers One thing that discussion I linked mentions is that almost every one of those 'analytic' functors must have unit 000, because only A×BA×BA×B can have unit 111. I'm not sure if there's an argument for more exotic cases, though.
(000 and 111 are the only possibilities for reasons that escape me.)

Dan Doel said:

(000 and 111 are the only possibilities for reasons that escape me.)

I wonder if it's something like this. Suppose the unit is SSS where SSS has at least two elements. Then SSS has nontrivial self-maps and those induce natural transformations A≅A⊗S→A⊗S≅AA \cong A \otimes S \to A \otimes S \cong AA≅A⊗S→A⊗S≅A. But the only natural transformation from the identity functor to itself is the identity. So, now if we plug in A=SA = SA=S do we get a contradiction somehow?
I think this does work, although it requires paying more attention to the axioms of a monoidal category than I'm used to.

Something about the left and right unitors agreeing on the unit object, so when you plug in A=SA = SA=S to this map, on one hand, it has to produce the identity map as I argued above, while on the other hand it also has to produce the original (non-identity) map S→SS \to SS→S.
Ah, interesting.
